==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|alt=玖-financial,𠔀,𢌬,𣲄}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etyl}}
{{liushu|p}} – a stylized hand, with bent wrist/forearm (hence the hook stroke at lower right). Earlier forms resemble {{zh-l|*手}}, {{zh-l|*寸}}. The original meaning of the glyph was “elbow”, which is now written {{och-l|肘}}.

After the meaning “elbow” was forgotten, {{lang|zh|九}} was taken to symbolize a [[fist]] tightening to [[bump up]] against something; thus, there is a metaphorical [[bumping]] up of [[nine]] against [[ten]], which is the the last number when counting on one's fingers.

===Etymology===
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*d/s-kəw}}. Compare {{cog|bo|དགུ}}.

===Definitions===
{{zh-hanzi}}

# [[nine]]
# {{lb|zh|figurative}} [[many]]
# {{lb|zh|weather}} each of the nine nine-day [[period]]s from the [[winter solstice]]

===Etymology 2===
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=きゅう}}. [[漢音#Japanese|Kan'on]], a later reading. Borrowed after palatalisation occurred in Middle Chinese.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|きゅう|y=ko}}
* {{audio|Ja-9-kyuu.ogg|Audio|lang=ja}}

====Number====
{{ja-pos|きゅう|numeral symbol|hhira=きう}}

# [[nine]]

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|きゅう|hhira=きう}}

# [[nine]]
# an [[indeterminate]] [[large]] [[number]], a [[myriad]], a great many
# {{lb|ja|sort=きゅう|divination}} the number of [[yang]], in opposition to {{m|ja|六|tr=roku||six}} as the number of [[yin]]

=====Alternative forms=====
* {{sense|large number}} {{ja-l|究}}

===Etymology 3===
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=ここの}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|ここの|y=kun}}

====Counter====
{{ja-pos|ここの|counter}}

# [[nine]]

===Etymology 4===
{{IPAchar|/kokono/}} → {{IPAchar|/kono/}}

Abbreviation of {{etyl|ojp|ja}} ''kokono'' (“nine”).

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|この|y=kun}}

====Number====
{{ja-pos|この|numeral symbol}}

# [[nine]]
#: {{ux|ja|ひい、ふう、みい、…なな、やあ、'''この'''、とお|tr=''hī, fū, mī, ... nana, yā, '''kono''', tō''|t=one, two, three, ... seven, eight, '''nine''', ten}}

=====Alternative forms=====
* {{ja-l|この}}

=====Usage notes=====
Generally only used when counting out loud, as in the example above. In writing, usually found spelled out in hiragana as {{ja-l|この}} to make the reading unambiguous.
